author: Daegoba
body:
I wouldn’t hold more than 6 months of monthly expenses in cash. The rest, I would spread over the safest, most fucking boring ass ETFs I could, some well-established stocks, a few index funds, and me? I’d “gamble” with maybe 5% on good potential up-and-coming companies in industries that show a strong promise of growth and expansion.

You have to have an emergency fund. There’s simply no telling what can happen day to day, and risking your livelihood just isn’t an option nowadays. I just got hit by a car 6 weeks ago and am unable to work. Luckily, I had an emergency fund to cover my bills or I would be colossally FUCKED.  $15-20k in cash is not going to make you rich invested over decades. Why risk it? It’s worth more if it’s kept close to insulate you in case of unforeseen circumstances. It simply doesn’t make sense not to. 

Fidelity, Vanguard, & TD all offer their own (as well as assess to) any and all small return/low risk ishares type shit to park good money in. They’re a great option to have as far as “safe” plays that will mostly keep pace with the markets and still not over leverage you as far as risk. 

The well-established individual stocks will always be a good play so long as you don’t get caught up in every little detail of day-to-day pricing. Anything in the top 20 of the S&P will keep you right on pace with the greater economy, and give you some security and reassurance that you’re getting the most out of your money. 

The “gambling” is what will keep you interested, educated, and give you potentially the most bang for your buck. I’m not talking about YOLO’s into some Foreign penny stock. I’m talking about common-sense plays that’s anyone who doesn’t have their head in the sand. Electric cars. 3D printing. Green Energy. Shit like that. These are budding industries that are obviously going to grow and expand over the next decade. Which companies will rise to the top? Who the fuck knows, but it’s sure as the weather that there’s a garage out there with the next Jobs, Bezos, or Musk out there right now. Why not try to catch it, and learn a little in the process?

author: babecafe
body:
Vanguard mutual funds avoid distributing taxable income by practicing a patented technique that involves performing derivative instrument swaps. Within a few years, this patent will expire and other companies' mutual funds may elect to use the same technique. Vanguard charges a $20 annual fee if the account balance is below $10k.

Fidelity, on the other hand, has no annual account fees, no matter the balance, and charges no fees to purchase stocks, ETF, or mutual funds. However, their mutual funds *will* distribute *some* taxable income once a year, due to dividends and realized capital trading gains. Because index funds do very little buying and selling of underlying stocks, though, this taxable income is usually a small amount.

If you invest your money into a conventional or Roth IRA, however, you need not concern yourself with the taxable income that may result from any investment, as dividends and capital gains are not taxed within these account types. You can contribute $6k per year ($7k/year for those over 50 years old) into either type of IRA per year, so you should be able to place about 2/3 of the amount you say you want to invest into an IRA account within three months.

author: doducduy96
body:
I buy VOO every month with 40% of my income. Whenever I feel anxious about my position, I take a deep breath, a day off and go for a walk/drive around town. When I walkout of the door, a AMZN package I ordered 18 hours ago had already been here, neat. Then I take out my AAPL phone and go to GOOGL to look for a place to eat/chill, just got my PFE vaccine last month so I’m good to go. Hoping into my trust worthy F F150 and starting to drive, I notice that hmmm I have been seeing a lot of TSLA cars around, maybe it’ll be my next car? I’m daydreaming. The drive is 5 miles, I wonder why the HDs, COSTs, WMTs, TGTs parking are always packed like that, even tho it’s only Wednesday, 
Hmmm guess I’ll skip groceries today. I feel lazy. Sitting at the restaurant’s outdoor patio, I enjoy my brunch with a glass of wine, my eyes start wandering around. What a beautiful day, the birds, the air, the people. Maybe it’s enough wine for the day, I go in to grab a soft drink. 8 out of 10 drinks on the fountain machine are KO products. Lots people around me are working on their AAPL and MSFT laptops. They are so thin yet very powerful. As a tech geek I know they are powered by INTC and AMD CPUs, and the heavy stuffs are done with NVIDIA GPUs. Gosh people are so productive nowadays! It’s time to leave, I lay my JPM V card to the tray, 5x points for dining baby! 5 mins later I’m on my way. Shit, I’m almost out of gas, pulling into a CVX gas station, tap my BAC MA card because I’ll get 3% cash back on Gas. Damn there’s a line wrapping around that MCD and SBUX drive thru, the food is unhealthy but well business is still booming I guess. 
Getting back into my home, I suddenly remember tomorrow is Oct 1st. I have T, VZ, NFLX bills to pay. 
Damn, I observed a lot from my lazy day today. I wonder what my life would be without all of the conveniences I saw today. 
I log into my Fidelity account and buy 4 more VOO shares. 
Feeling good.

author: StCrispin1969
body:
I use RH for options because the “legitimate” brokerages I have (TD Ameritrade and Fidelity) charge 65c a contract to buy or sell, scrape off 3c a transaction on both ends, and also charge 2c “SEC fee” on each end, making the total throughput in and out somewhere around $1.45 meaning you don’t make anything from a weekly, THEY do though…

RH on the other hand takes a penny or so off the top on an assignment (a $1.50 short call pays me $149.99 or 3 of them pays 149.99 on 2 and 149.98 on the third) and no other noticeable fees.

I have caught them doing magic math though.  Where I sell a contract for 0.07 it says I got a 0.09 premium but when it expires it reverts back to 0.07 which leads me to believe they really sold the 9 but told me it was 7 and kept 2 for themself. Weird math sometimes).

And then there is Fidelity (aka Fido, aka the dog) who locks your account when you buy 4.5 million shares of a 0.0001 pink to “protect you” from yourself and tell you that you can only sell from now on, not buy.  Then when you sell that $450 worth of stock for $15,000 they get mad and refuse to let you take out your money for a year.  Next February I should be able to make a withdrawal.  They call it “clearing” but I call it “suckling my teet for interest on 15k for a full year”.  They still won’t let me buy stocks.  Dicks.

RH followed Fido’s example with the GME stupidity.  They didn’t invent that tactic.  They were just too small to get away with it.

author: yakadayaka
body:
"people that really have no business speculating on stocks"

For far too long investing in the stock market has been the domain of the wealthy elite. The premise for this is predicated by capitalism, of course. The ordinary folk are expected to spend every penny they earn or can borrow so that the companies the wealthy are invested in can rake in massive profits. 

The tide is slowly turning, and more and more people, particularly the younger folk, have begun to learn the ropes of investing. And are happy to do it by themselves using low cost funds rather than through an intermediary (aka financial advisor) and high cost mutual funds. If you visited Fidelity Canada's website just 10 years ago you would have noticed that it was pitched toward investment advisors - and how they can help their clients. Not so any more - and it's the same with other companies like Vanguard as well. 

The new investors stepped into the market in March last year because they had learned to recognize value. Stocks, in spite of the risks of Covid, were ridiculously cheap. They stepped in and set the floor on a market that traders would have happily shorted until it went even lower. 

So yes, the shoe shine boys are now becoming savvy investors. What would be interesting to see is how such a democratization of investing would impact corporate bottom lines in 15 - 20 years. After all, Zeus help us all if the people who are supposed to borrow and spend suddenly start saving and investing.

author: kjb123etc
body:
The S&P 500 is an index. You can't invest in it directly.

There are many S&P 500 index *funds* - these are what you can invest in. They are set up to track the S&P 500, meaning they buy and sell shares in the constituent companies in order to achieve the same weightings and performance of the S&P 500 itself... minus management fees (expense ratios). 

You can Google individual S&P 500 index funds to see what their differences are. In general any index fund offered by Vanguard, Fidelity or Schwab is going to be pretty cheap (again look at the expense ratio). They basically all do the same thing aside from charging slightly different fees.

You may have more luck with your other questions in r/personalfinance as it's a much larger subreddit.

author: yakadayaka
body:
"people that really have no business speculating on stocks"

For far too long investing in the stock market has been the domain of the wealthy elite. The premise for this is predicated by capitalism, of course. The ordinary folk are expected to spend every penny they earn or can borrow so that the companies the wealthy are invested in can rake in massive profits. 

The tide is slowly turning, and more and more people, particularly the younger folk, have begun to learn the ropes of investing. And are happy to do it by themselves using low cost funds rather than through an intermediary (aka financial advisor) and high cost mutual funds. If you visited Fidelity Canada's website just 10 years ago you would have noticed that it was pitched toward investment advisors - and how they can help their clients. Not so any more - and it's the same with other companies like Vanguard as well. 

The new investors stepped into the market in March last year because they had learned to recognize value. Stocks, in spite of the risks of Covid, were ridiculously cheap. They stepped in and set the floor on a market that traders would have happily shorted until it went even lower. 

So yes, the shoe shine boys are now becoming savvy investors. What would be interesting to see is how such a democratization of investing would impact corporate bottom lines in 15 - 20 years. After all, Zeus help us all if the people who are supposed to borrow and spend suddenly start saving and investing.

author: MaintenanceCall
body:
There have been a couple discussions on this subject on this sub and others, I'd suggest doing a search about the tax implications of covered calls. Fidelity has a introductory article on the subject which is helpful as well. *: A keyword you might want to look up is "holding period". Selling contracts on stock affects the holding periods.    
  
The two big things I'd note is that:   
1. Collecting premium is a taxable event.   
2. Selling "unqualified" options contracts can create taxable events as well. Generally, selling in the money covered calls is effectively selling the stock (since it's likely to be executed) so the IRS treats it as selling the stock. This means that the capital gains rate is whatever it would be for the stock the day you open the contract. 
  
The devil is in the details of course, but essentially, be aware that selling in the money calls on stock you've owned less than a year is likely to be taxed as short term capital gains. 
  
Out of the money contracts and stock you've held longer than a year pretty much avoids these issues though.

author: LiqCourage
body:
You may not think you are good at math but you have a better handle on your current financial picture than most people your age.  This is good!  give yourself a pat on the back.

I didn't note any mention of an emergency fund.  This should be cash that can be used to cover your living expenses fully for 3-6 months if something really goes wrong.  if you don't have that, start prioritizing cash flow to build that up.

And yes, maximize your retirement benefit plans.  On the 403b, make sure you are getting the maximum match.  I can't tell for sure from the way you have described it, but if you are missing any % on the match, that is free money that you should prioritize getting (some employers match the first x% of your salary... if that is 10% in this case you should increase your contribution to 10%).  On a cash flow basis if you have to pick between getting the maximum match in 403b over maxing out Roth IRA, get the 403b match first, then try to max the Roth.  Prioritize those two goals above money you put into taxable investing.

IMO, Fidelity was the right choice of the two providers you mentioned, as you can build a wider relationship with them over time and they have a lot of other financial options.  Set up your brokerage account with them if you haven't already.  You did mention VTSAX so maybe you already have a set up with Vanguard.

regarding funds: at your age capital appreciation is the best goal.  keep it simple and manageable.  I would pick the Fid 500 as large cap is the right strategy at this stage of the bull market and at your age and investment horizon.  The other fund is target age fund (typically a fund that holds other Fidelity funds and changes allocation over time along with your expected retirement age).  This will be better during a down market for sure than the other, but I don't see one of those for a while.  So pay attention and plan to change allocation when a bear market comes along.

Keeping it simple makes things easier to manage, while you grow your understanding of investing.  Best wishes!

author: Codesandstuff
body:
So when you are selling a call you are doing just that, writing an option that you sell to a counterparty. This means you are short this call your counterparty can exercise the call which forces you to sell this counterparty 100 shares (per call) at the designated strike price.

What it sounds like you are describing is Covered Calls and Naked Calls. Covered simply means you already own 100 shares, so you sell what you already own. Naked means when assigned you have to go onto the open market, buy 100 shares at the current price, and sell them to your counterparty at the strike price.

What this means functionally is if you are not covered you are subject to theoretically infinite loss because there is no ceiling to what price a stock could get to.

A basic example: You sell a call at a strike of 10 but do not own the stock. If the option is exercised and the stock price is 100? You must go out and buy 100 shares at 100/sh and sell them at 10/sh, incurring a loss of 90/sh.

Being "Covered" is represented differently on different brokers. I use Fidelity and they also do not explicitly say whether my covered calls are covered or not.

Another notable difference is you should not be able to open naked calls if you are not approved for the proper level of options (level 4). Same with covered calls but they require a looser level (level 1).

edit: [Here's](https://www.investopedia.com/ask/answers/032615/what-difference-between-covered-call-and-regular-call.asp#:~:text=An%20investor%20in%20a%20naked,generates%20income%20for%20the%20investor) a good source that probably describes this better :)

author: throwawayinvestacct
body:
> Would it be a correct statement that if my overall portfolio consistently shows higher gains than the S&P and/or VTI, then I’m “beating the market”? . . . And, conversely, if my portfolio consistently has lower gains than those indexes, I’m better off just putting everything into the index instead?

No, because of the point you recognized with your next example:

>A more specific example: let’s say (hypothetically) my portfolio is like 70% tech stocks, should I be comparing my performance to QQQ? It makes sense in my mind, just want to make sure my logic is correct.

That is probably a closer analogue, yes. 

The reason QQQ is the better benchmark (and why beating the S&P with such a profile wouldn't necessarily be "beating the market") is you've bought a riskier portfolio, so *should* see greater returns as a result. "Beating the market" tends to be discussed in terms of *risk-adjusted* returns. 

If you have a portfolio that is much riskier than the S&P and outperform it by 1%, you haven't "beaten" the S&P, you haven't generated any [alpha](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/a/alpha.asp) as an investor, you've just added risk. As with your QQQ example, if you just want that added risk, you could just buy QQQ instead of S&P to get that added risk without your stockpicking.

>I use Fidelity, and the performance page says (I think) that my personal return over the last 3 months is 36% higher than the return of S&P, but I’m not sure if I’m reading it right or if that metric is useful at all.

The other thing to remember is that short-term overperformance is no guarantee of *long-term* overperformance. Looking to the 2017 year-end SPIVA "scorecard", roughly 40% of US fund managers [managed to beat their benchmark index over one year](https://www.aei.org/carpe-diem/more-evidence-that-its-very-hard-to-beat-the-market-over-time-95-of-financial-professionals-cant-do-it/) (after fees). Heck, a *majority* of mid- and small-cap fund managers did. But, over the *long* haul (3, 5, 10, 15 years) that edge quickly vanished, and the vast majority underperformed their benchmark index.

author: a77asad
body: HPQ Silicon Resources (HPQ.V / HPQ.FF)- Company has developed patent pending processes to become lowest cost producer of pure silicon metal, Silicon nano-powders and nano wires. Other than numerous applications in the chemical, medical and solar industry, what interests me most is the use of silicon in the battery storage industry to improve the Li-ion battery performance. As per UBS, energy storage industry could grow to 426 billion in next 10 years. HPQ's tech potential has already generated NDA's with battery manufacturers and advanced material companies. In addition, HPQ has received firm order for Si nano powders from major car manufacturer.

author: ZhangtheGreat
body: Remember when IBM dominated computing? Pepperidge Farm remembers.

author: Elster-
body:
I don’t think Apple will be at the top forever. No company stays at the top forever. 

Another company comes along and will beat it. 

There have been oil companies that people said ‘well we will always need oil, so they’ll always be up there’

There have been product companies like P&G who own 90% of what you buy who you’d think would never be out of the top

There have been tech companies like Cisco & IBM and people thought tech was here to stay, it was but someone better will always come along.

Who knows what the next big market cap will come from.

author: donm527
body: The “blue chips” of past... IBM, GE, CISCO, AOL, BlackBerry... they were blue chips because in their time they changed the world and set the path of progress in their areas. They didn’t fail... they just didn’t predict the next generation of tech or products and couldn’t keep up. IBM... they did pretty good if you see they started with typewriters and made the transition to computers. But Apple taking PCs to the consumer and using a GUI and mouse to make the average person be able to use one changed the world. Taking smartphones from a business only to the consumer with $20 data plan reachable to the average consumer... changed the world. While competitors laughed saying no one will spend that kind of money on it (Ballmer monkey boy) and others said no keyboard it won’t go far (Balckberry). Very tough to be able to lead for that long. Who knew a online bookstore would lead the world in cloud services??

author: Wholesome_Stuff
body: NET seems like a difficult stock to rate. In the past few years cyber attacks have become more prevalent, and will continue to be. Microsoft, Google, Oracle, IBM, Apple and i'm sure plenty of others have partnered with them. Besides their PEG ratio is -11.28, out of the ones you listed this is the lowest by more than double. I.e. they are the best deal for future earnings.

author: hendrix_srv
body:
Every Balmer acquisition was written off as worthless.  Had they chosen someone other than Nadella to replace Balmer, MSFT might be with IBM.

I have a database that tracks revenues of many companies back to 2000, and I can select any group of companies and plot the revenue chart.  My "tech majors" groups is an astounding chart, with AAPL coming from the bottom and charting a steep course to the top in 05-10, and IBM and ORCL climbing early on then arcing back into the basement.

It could definitely be replaced just like any other company, but I think Apple has a great chance at still being #1 in 20 years.

author: ShadowLiberal
body:
IBM was so huge that 8 out of 10 programmers used to go work for IBM.

IBM was so huge that they used to purposely overbid on jobs so that that their competition could win enough of them to keep IBM just under 80% of the market share. Because if they got any bigger they knew that the US government would probably try to break them up under anti-monopoly laws.

So yeah, a lot of people loved IBM, you practically had to use them at one point.

author: Ledovi
body: IBM, AT&T

author: abrasiveteapot
body:
There's a long list of companies who failed because of the desire to protect a legacy business despite obvious signs it was getting replaced. Xerox is a great one, but there's also Kodak and IBM (protected mainframes far too long before pivoting at 5secs to midnight), Nokia, Blackberry etc. 

And of course there's the situation right now with most legacy car manufacturers, Toyota in particular. 

The problem with disruption is it happens fast, just ask Nokia. Or look at the number of cars on the road in 1906 vs 1912 (pretty sure that's the right dates, but if not there was a like 5 year period where cars went from a handful to tens of thousands to "everywhere" same as smartphones)

author: kok823
body: Yes, but you need at least a plausible theory as to why Apple would be on a MAJOR downtrend. It’s silly to say because we had examples of GE, IBM, etc. therefore the same thing would happen to Apple.

author: Traditional-Leader54
body:
If you don’t need the royalty payments now I would suggest looking into a retirement account and just let your money grow over the next 40 years. In the US these are tax deferred until age 55 or 62 depending on the plan. 

If you want the payments now I’d look into dividend stocks. They are stocks that pay you money (I think quarterly) based on how many shares you have and how much money the company made that quarter. Think CocaCola, Microsoft, IBM, Apple, etc. Companies that earn consistently and aren’t going anywhere. This is less risky than investing in a startup company for a true royalty that only lasts if the company does. 

Either way talk to a stock broker for more info.

author: rock00888
body:
I don't think technology is particularly high risk or anything. It's not crazy speculative or anything. But what happens if a chip that consumes basically zero power comes out of a start up tomorrow? Or what happens if US anti trust enforcement kicks up? Particularly in tech things can change quickly. Not generally for the sector, but for individual companies. Xerox, IBM, et c. all saw huge swings. Any single sector carries it's own risk. 

I don't think tech is going anywhere. I don't see a way tech changes radically anytime soon, but it's the radical changes we don't see coming that do the most damage.

author: SnipahShot
body:
Your comments seem like you are a 5 year old.

"Do you really think the super smart people they hire are morons that will sit around and let AAPL go under?"

Hundreds of companies had "super smart" people.  
Are you familiar with Nokia? BlockBuster? BlackBerry? IBM?  
Heck, even Intel has been trading downwards for almost 6 months.

It doesn't matter how many "super smart people" a company has, if a company fails to innovate and expand their business they will start going down.  
This is not the case for Apple, but it is not because of "super smart people", it is because they still seem to innovate and expand.

Also, do you even know what exactly Apple are planning on doing in the healthcare and EV? Who their competition is in each of these fields?

author: shortyafter
body:
You don't have anything like Tesla or ARK funds, which is good.  I'm not deeply familiar with most of these companies, so I don't know what their revenue streams or growth prospects look like.  What I can say is that a lot of those names have been trading very high lately... AMD, Nvidia, TSM, ASML, etc. Those companies in particular all seem to have bright futures, but if there is any significant correction in tech stocks, you're very exposed, especially if you bought recently at high valuations.  You'll have very little margin of safety.

And if there's any broader economic disruption, it's possible that not all of these companies make it out safe and sound, or at least as healthy as you'd like to seem them given current valuations.

For example, even good companies like Cisco didn't make it out in one piece from the dot-com bubble.  And old industry leaders like IBM and Intel have gotten hammered in the past two decades, while Microsoft made something of a surprise comeback after being declared dead around 2012.

The point is that if you've bought growth stories, that's OK, but it seems your whole portfolio is growth stories.  It's forward-looking.  Which is the idea, in a way, but IMO you want at least some of your portfolio dedicated to something that is solid in the present, and doesn't rely on a growth story in order to generate or even maintain returns.  The benefit of an ETF is you get a bit of everything, and even QQQ is quite diversified compared to your portfolio.  

I'm new but this is my understanding of things.  I hope it made sense.

author: sublette313
body:
I've never sold a single share and I could've gotten out at 40 moron. I've DCA'd on LEAPS expiring 2023 all fucking year. Anyone who buys and sells this company at this 22-26 range and thinks they're Gordon gecko are fucking morons.

Scalability has been proven time and time again much much more bullish than bearish. Amazon and IBM partnerships as well as others, they can deploy Foundry completely remotely without having any on-site engineers for products like Foundry for builders and many other versions. Their margins would look significantly better if they hadn't just gone on an absolute hiring tear by the way. They've dramatically increased hiring sales employees this year as they ramp up distribution which guess what? They're using the SBC to ensure this massive hiring they're doing is focused on the long term and is way better for shareholders than simply paying them in cash. Maybe if you had any idea what the company is actually doing you'd see right away that these bear cases are missing the entire point of how they're growing the company. author: Traditional-Leader54
body:
If you don’t need the royalty payments now I would suggest looking into a retirement account and just let your money grow over the next 40 years. In the US these are tax deferred until age 55 or 62 depending on the plan. 

If you want the payments now I’d look into dividend stocks. They are stocks that pay you money (I think quarterly) based on how many shares you have and how much money the company made that quarter. Think CocaCola, Microsoft, IBM, Apple, etc. Companies that earn consistently and aren’t going anywhere. This is less risky than investing in a startup company for a true royalty that only lasts if the company does. 

Either way talk to a stock broker for more info.

author: Lyrolepis
body:
The problem is that ten years ago, when your backtest starts, Tesla for example *was* a relatively new company, and it was not at all obvious - except perhaps to some domain experts, possibly, but I'm doubtful - that it would have been so successful. 

> If you don’t feel that the market leaders are going to provide good returns moving forward (which is pretty ridiculous to think)

If it was so obvious that TSLA and the others were going to keep growing (let alone as quickly as they have), their current price would already reflect this (just as the fact that TSLA had a relatively low price ten years ago reflected the fact that it was a relatively risky investment then). 

Remember, there was a time IBM was a "market leader" too, and a wildly successful one too (not the only possible example, only the first one that came to my mind). 

Note, I am not saying that the companies you selected are not going to be successful in the future - for all I know, they could well be. 

I'm not even saying that you should not do that: as you wrote, it's just one euro per day, even in a worst case scenario that's not something that is likely to ruin you (if it *is*, you have bigger worries than investing). But I'm saying that I would not expect your backtest to give reliable estimates on the return of your investment.

author: Goddess_Peorth
body:
Nope, I'm reading it in Firefox on a linux desktop.

Having lots of users doesn't matter. Just like, chrome having lots of users doesn't tell you which is more popular in a certain industry. More people using phones for internet than full computers also doesn't help tell you what people use at work.

Cloud services are only profitable in the business to business uses. Businesses using google cloud are more likely to be doing so because they have small needs, they're not spending money on network services. Businesses who have core business "in the cloud" are using AWS, Microsoft, or IBM. Google can't really tap into that business, because their history of cancelling services means that nobody builds their core business on top of google services. It would be a completely insane thing to do.

Autonomous driving is snake oil, because they're using trained AI. That's a dead end for this use case, because what happens when the Dept. of Transportation tells you, "In XYZ situation, you need to do A B and C and never L M or N." You can't! You don't even know how your software really works with a trained AI. It takes a long time to make small changes. It will never be more than a type of cruise control, until companies bite the bullet and put the programming hours into expert systems. (Source: day job includes writing robotics firmware)

author: shortyafter
body:
You don't have anything like Tesla or ARK funds, which is good.  I'm not deeply familiar with most of these companies, so I don't know what their revenue streams or growth prospects look like.  What I can say is that a lot of those names have been trading very high lately... AMD, Nvidia, TSM, ASML, etc. Those companies in particular all seem to have bright futures, but if there is any significant correction in tech stocks, you're very exposed, especially if you bought recently at high valuations.  You'll have very little margin of safety.

And if there's any broader economic disruption, it's possible that not all of these companies make it out safe and sound, or at least as healthy as you'd like to seem them given current valuations.

For example, even good companies like Cisco didn't make it out in one piece from the dot-com bubble.  And old industry leaders like IBM and Intel have gotten hammered in the past two decades, while Microsoft made something of a surprise comeback after being declared dead around 2012.

The point is that if you've bought growth stories, that's OK, but it seems your whole portfolio is growth stories.  It's forward-looking.  Which is the idea, in a way, but IMO you want at least some of your portfolio dedicated to something that is solid in the present, and doesn't rely on a growth story in order to generate or even maintain returns.  The benefit of an ETF is you get a bit of everything, and even QQQ is quite diversified compared to your portfolio.  

I'm new but this is my understanding of things.  I hope it made sense.

Yeah it’s a good question and I should’ve clarified. Each of the 13 national quantum centers have a leading national labs, several partner institutions (universities) and then at least 3-4 industry (commercial) partners. 

So commercial partners are involved with every quantum center as far as I’ve seen. 

For example, Q-NEXT at Argonne is partnered with industry partners IBM, Intel, Boeing, Verizon and ColdQuanta to name a few. 

QSA (Berkeley) is partnered with Google, IBM and QED-C. 

SQMS (Fermilab) is partnered with Rigetti, Lockheed Martin, Janis and Goldman Sachs.

C2QA (Brookhaven) has IBM mainly, and then nearly all the Ivy League schools. 

It goes on.

author: Bamstradamus
body:
DDR5 news might provide a pop, but they would still have to sell the memory.  I have said it over and over on CRSR posts, this chip shortage is not ending any time soon, the vast majority of people are still waiting on GPU's to upgrade anything, especially since at higher resolutions the bottleneck moves from the CPU to the GPU, you can run 4k60 on a first gen Ryzen as long as you have a GPU capable of outputting the frames.

Add to that historically the first set of chips on a new DDR is typically slower then the previous gens top tier, the fact all RAM is essentially the same since their are only 3 major manufacturers and everyone just repackages those chips, GSkill probably outbidding everyone else for "the good chip" at the start again *seriously did any of you even build a Ryzen system, Corsair had like 4 compatible sku's for the entire 300 series chipsets life, Gskill got all the B-die*
and the fact we don't have any real world specs to work with yet I don't know anyone chomping at the bit for the DDR5 release.

I can see the news drop leading to a pop, I do not see DDR5 sales making an actual contribution to value until the NEXT set of chipsets come from AMD/Intel.

author: GraysonMA
body:
When you buy leaps you are taking on a lot of vega exposure which can add significant risk to your portfolio. However, vega gives you a second way to win if you stick to companies that have IVR/IV% near their 52 week lows. [Barchart is a great resource for finding these.](https://www.barchart.com/options/iv-rank-percentile/stocks?orderBy=optionsWeightedImpliedVolatility&orderDir=asc)
I also choose underlyings that have low correlation with each other. This keeps things a little less volatile which is especially important using any type of leverage. [PortfolioVisualizer has a great tool for this.](https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/asset-correlations?s=y&symbols=SPY+TLT+KO+PG+D+INTC+MCD+VZ+FB+MSFT+NVDA+LLY+NEE&timePeriod=2&tradingDays=60&months=36). Leaps I bought recently are in PG, INTC, FB, D, MSFT, KO, VZ, and MCD. LLY is an solid low correlation pick but I’m waiting for a dip in IV.

author: donktastic
body:
That's not completely true and even if it was it doesn't matter. The proprietary tech steps are all done in secure locations like the US, Israel and Ireland with the US doing 100% of their R&D. The R&D sites are massive and also do manufacturing which handles the most top secret stuff, like US military stuff. Asia only gets the cost saving steps that are not sensitive, like packaging. 

If shit hit the fan and world war 3 broke out, Intel could easily do 100% of its process in the US or allied countries. The most important part being that Intel is a US company, is based in the USA and is invested in the success of the nation.

author: Economy-Cup5465
body:
It is extremely nuanced. 

\>The thesis is that Tesla is far ahead in its self-driving capabilities that other car makers just can't catch up. And because they already have cars on the road now, they are collecting more data which is making their lead wider.

It is my view that the FSD tech would be more of an open space. Most of these companies will start using third party companies, akin to how PC manufacturers used Windows from Microsoft instead of creating their own OS. Initially some will try their hand at the market with their own bespoke solution(like the wild west days of 80's when we had commodores and sinclair spectrums). However after some time their will be a standardization(IBM PC). 

At best I can see Tesla becoming like the Macintoshes:  
Tesla: Proprietary full self driving system:: Macintoshes : Proprietary OSes

\>If any company is way ahead in self-driving, it's actually Waymo, not Tesla. They just launched a self-driving taxi service in San Francisco, a dense city with weird roads and many pedestrians.  
Tesla is boasting about FSD(which is between a very good cruise and a poor self driver). The key difference between waymo and tesla is that tesla is heavily reliant on an AI based system, whereas waymo(which does use AI) is heavily dependent on Geolocation and real time data.

\]>The thesis is that Tesla is far ahead in its self-driving capabilities that other car makers just can't catch up. And because they already have cars on the road now, they are collecting more data which is making their lead wider.

Run away from any person who says that leads are insurmountable. Just look at Intel. Went from being a market leader to being overtaken by near bankrupt competitors(See: AMD)

author: Overhaul2977
body:
AMD’s profit margin is pretty good, they are taking market share from intel and approaching Nvidia in performance for their GPUs, and they are innovating well under current management. The problem with your analysis is you’re looking at book value, you need to look at future growth and both companies they can take market share have a fair amount higher market cap, meaning it has plenty of space to grow if things keep going well for them. The stock market cares about future growth, not too much on past performance.

To give you a basic idea of investing, there are four types of companies - Dogs, Cash Cows, Question Marks, and Stars. AMD is at the Question Mark phase that is almost to Star. They are taking market share in a fast growing area. The typical investor strategy in that situation is to “buy”.

author: Summebride
body:
Stocks means stock market securities that you've surely heard of, Microsoft, Intel, JP Morgan, etc.

Bonds are a timed instrument where you lend your money to something and they pay it back later, with a slight amount extra.

Bonds have traditionally been for old people as they neither go up or down very much, and are predictable.  

Stocks can change in value radically and have traditionally been recommended for young  people so if you lose a lot of value, you have time to make it up.  

Blended fund just means a mix of those two kinds of things.  

At 23 there's no other choice than stock.  

AAR% likely means average annual return.  So if the AAR% was 4% and you have 1000 placed there, it would have gained about $40 during the year.  

Bunds are have recently been returning close to nothing.  Someday that might change but for now they're pretty much a worthless option for you.

author: Hani95
body:
So I'm actually going to do some market analysis on the direction of the market, and I'd like thoughts and a discussion if possible. Think Socratic discussion. 

In the U.S. I think that the markets are going to soon start a rotation to value, and you can sort of see it starting to occur as bond yields have started to rise, meaning that growth stocks will start to become less attractive relative to value stocks. You've been seeing supply chain and logistics companies like Matson, Maersk, Zim, and other assorted shipping stocks boom during this time period. Commodities stocks in the aluminum sector are poised to outperform, because Guyana just had a coup, and it's a huge exporter of aluminum... Especially to China. With that said, steel and iron ore are the same with exports to China from Australia of iron ore outperforming despite negative relations between these two nations. Both of these types of stocks have outperformed year-to-date, and will continue to do so for the next month or two as forward looking investors look at commentary stating that supply chain, and commodity prices will be elevated well into next week. Finally, home builders have outperformed, and are poised to continue their outperformance due to a massive shortage of homes that will take years to a decade to fix.

I believe in the latter months, in 2022, and heading into 2023 financials will outperform as yields for the 10 year T note rise. First, domestic debit and credit card transaction volume will rise (which bank CEO's , and Visa's CEO, have noted has already started to happen), and this will be followed by international travel spend (Which is very lucrative). This will primarily help Visa, and Mastercard as they have been essentially flat year to date and on a yearly basis. It will also help American Express, and Discover Financial to a lesser extent. Then, credit card balances will grow and forward looking investors will start looking at interest rate hikes by the FED in late 2022-2023, which is the one-two punch that bank stocks will need to see outsize profitability. The strong M&A activity, even in the face of anti-trust scrutiny, is also helping banks. Third, ADP and other benefit provider/payroll companies will do well as payrolls continue to increase, and unemployment continues to go down. The runway is still clear there. Then, there are the mortgage companies where there currently has been a pricing war which should cool sometime in early 2022, allowing for Gain on Sale margins to normalize to roughly 115-185BPS, while the value of their Mortgage servicing rights should increase alongside the yield for the 10YR T notes. Open banking should continue its outperformance, with strong markets in Asia, the Middle East, Europe, and Latin and South America, and growing adoption in North America. Companies like Paysafe, PAG, Razer, etcetera should do well in this environment. Finally, the moratorium on school loan payments should cease very soon allowing companies like Navient and Sofi to regain momentum.

I also believe that airlines will start to outperform starting in Q1-Q2 2022, as flight restrictions start falling away, and business travel starts to resume at a more normal tempo. Personally, Delta Airlines and the budget airlines are my preferred ones. Then, there are homebuilders who will continue their outperformance as they have significantly deleveraged and still have long runways for price to earnings growth. I'd expect dividend increases in the latter half of 2022 to reflect this. Third is General Electric under Larry Culp, who's turnaround efforts haven't recently been noticed, but who's conducted strong execution. From their wind turbines, to their jet engines, to their medical division, there is strong growth to be had and I believe we'll see a spurt in the share price to reflect the reality of 2022 and Culp's momentous turn around. I also believe chip fabricators (and chip designers) will outperform. TSM has been relatively flat in the last 3 months, save for a one week burst of over 5% to reflect the fact that they're increasing prices across the board from 10 to 20%. Intel, meanwhile, is building a chip fabrication plant in Ireland which will be entirely dedicated to vehicle chip manufacturing, which I think will be a success. Finally, I believe the used car (autonation), and new car companies such as Ford and GM as well as Volkswagen will outperform in 2022 due to the scarcity of vehicles, compounded by Hurricane Ida's destruction of numerous vehicles (And the risk that other natural disasters destroy even more vehicles).

The China rally, meanwhile, is unsustainable in the light of the regulatory tempo on the free market principle that China ever so briefly embraced. In light of all these actions, it is my firm belief that  China is, or will, embrace capitalism "with chinese characteristics." The crackdowns are far from over, and I believe the state will go further in the realm of entertainment and video streaming, such as suspending screen time for minors on video streaming platforms (something they already do) to a level consistent to where they've placed video gaming limits to combat the myopia epidemic as well as fan culture. They are also likely to crackdown on drinking establishments, and liquor companies to crack down on the excessive drinking in China, in an attempt to stave off chronic health conditions that could accrue, as well as crack down on companies trying to profiteer off a rapidly aging China. These are just a few sectors where I see potential intervention, but there are likely others. The fact that systematic debt has reached such dizzying levels in China is also worrying, and presents a structural issue. A house of cards, if you will. The fact that JD bought an insignificant sum of shares, means that there is a rally in tech stock shares today is foolish, especially since it's broad based and not tailored means there's no solid shoring. Furthermore, the debt to equity levels for some companies, such as Iqiyi, Evergrande, and other stocks is extremely worrying.

I believe emerging market stocks in Brazil, Mexico, India, the Middle East, and Turkey present better opportunities.
